solution: To find the volume of the figure, start by breaking it up into 3 rectangular prisms.

Now, find the volume of each prism. Start with the top prism. Notice that its height is the difference between the height of the whole figure, 5 centimetres, and the height of the bottom left prism, 3 centimetres.
The length $\ell$ is 10 centimetres. The width $w$ is 3 centimetres. The height $h$ is 2 centimetres.

V = $\ell \times w \times h$
V= 10 $\times$ 3 $\times$ 2
V= 60
The volume of the top prism is 60 cubic centimetres.
Now, find the volume of the bottom left prism. Notice that its width is the same as the top prism, 3 centimetres.
The length $\ell$ is 3 centimetres. The width $w$ is 2 centimetres. The height $h$ is 3 centimetres.

V = $\ell \times w \times h$
V= 3 $\times$ 2 $\times$ 3
V= 18
The volume of the bottom left prism is 18 cubic centimetres.

The length $\ell$ is 3 centimetres. The width $w$ is 2 centimetres. The height $h$ is 3 centimetres.

V = $\ell \times w \times h$
V= 3 $\times$ 2 $\times$ 3
V= 18
The volume of the bottom right prism is 18 cubic centimetres.

To find the total volume of the figure, add the volumes of the prisms.
60 + 18 + 18 = 96
The volume of the figure is 96 cubic centimetres.
